s.text: There, near Cold Mountain, waits his sweetheart, a woman called Ada Monroe.
Most people don't want novels to be, in the deepest sense, unreal.
In short, Frazier sacrifices aesthetic life to historical life.
The result is that while one continues to believe Cold Mountain on the surface, one stops believing it at any deeper level.
There is a false consciousness to a late 20 th -century writer's efforts to evoke a 19 th -century man in a language that belongs to neither.
When Inman is seduced, for instance, he places his hand on the woman's leg, high up.
But the novel is a refined exercise.
But the novel is a refined exercise.
But the novel is a refined exercise.
But the novel is a refined exercise.
But the novel is a refined exercise.
But the novel is a refined exercise.
But the novel is a refined exercise.
Although the novelist might be able to render well all sorts of facts and dates and general furniture, she could never truthfully render the "old consciousness."

So we have a man's tongue "grey as the foot of a goose"; a catfish "the size of a boar hog"; a man who gets ready to take a blow "like a cowed dog"; a night as dark "as the inside of a cow"; an old man whose dugs "hung down like those on a sow hog"--an entire farmyard of likenesses.

You will not hear this from the readers and judges who have helped make Charles Frazier's Civil War tale probably the most popular novel about that period since Gone With the Wind . (Since its publication in June, Cold Mountain has sold more than a million copies; in November, it won the National Book Award.)
